content.text: The length of the pool is \(50.0 \text{m}\)
Name a suitable piece of equipment that could be used to measure the length of the pool
Determine the time taken by the winner to swim \(50.0 \text{m}\). Use information from Fig. 1.2
winner's time =   .........  \(s\)
[ii) Calculate the average speed of the winner
average speed =   .........  \(m/s\)
[iii) Calculate the time difference between the winner and the swimmer in second place
The race starts and the students swim to the end of the \(50.0 \text{m}\) pool
Fig. 1.2 shows the times recorded on the stop watches for the winner and the swimmer in second place
Fig. 1.1 shows students about to start a \(50.0 \text{m}\) swimming race
Determine the mass of the paint
mass of paint =   .........  \(g\)
Calculate the density of the paint. Include the unit
density =   .........
The walls of a room are to be painted
A tin of paint has a total mass of \(7000\mathrm{g}\) and a volume of \(5000\mathrm{cm}^3\)
The empty tin has a mass of \(500\mathrm{g}\)
The painter drops a brush into the tin of paint. The brush floats
Suggest why the brush floats
The sunshade has a mass of \(20.0 \text{kg}\)
Calculate the weight of the sunshade
weight =   .........  N
Another sunshade is shown in Fig. 3.2
This sunshade weighs 180 N
The arm holding the sunshade extends \(2.5 \text{m}\) from the pivot
Calculate the moment of the sunshade about the pivot
moment =   .........  Nm
How can the moment produced by the sunshade be reduced? Tick **one** box
by decreasing the height of the support
by decreasing the length of the arm holding the sunshade
by increasing the weight of the base
by increasing the weight of the sunshade
Fig. 3.1 shows a large sunshade
The arm holding the sunshade pivots about the end of a support
State the name of the process by which thermal energy is transferred from the Sun to the Earth
Fig. 4.2 shows part of the white wall and the black door of the house. Two thermometers have been attached, one to the wall and the other to the door
Thermometer A measures the temperature of the white wall. Thermometer B measures the temperature of the black door
The thermometer readings are recorded after the Sun has been shining on the house for some time
Suggest which thermometer has the higher temperature and explain why
higher temperature
explanation
The Sun is shining on the door and the front wall of the house
The air conditioning unit inside a room in the house is switched on. The air conditioning unit takes in warm air and gives out cold air, as shown in Fig. 4.3
Explain how the air conditioning unit cools all the air in the room
A house has white wooden walls and a black wooden door, as shown in Fig. 4.1
A potato snack packet is taken onto an aeroplane. During the flight the pressure inside the aeroplane changes and the potato snack packet changes shape, as shown in Fig. 5.1
potato snack packet before flight potato snack packet during flight
Explain why the packet changes shape. Use ideas about the gas molecules inside and outside the packet in your answer
A deep-sea diver on a diving-boat experiences atmospheric pressure. When she is working underwater, she experiences an increased pressure
State **two** factors that affect the size of the increased pressure
State the name of the device shown in Fig. 5.2
Fig. 5.3 shows a manometer connected to a gas supply. The pressure of the gas supply is greater than atmospheric pressure. Atmospheric pressure is equal to \(1033.6 \text{cm}\) of water
Determine the pressure of the gas supply
pressure =   .........  \(cm\) of water
Fig. 5.2 shows a device used for measuring atmospheric pressure
A ray of light from car 1 is shown
On Fig. 6.1, clearly draw the normal to the plane mirror where this ray hits the plane mirror. Label the normal N.
On Fig. 6.1, carefully draw the reflected ray of light
State the law used in your answer to (a)(ii)
Can each driver see the other car?
Explain your answer
Fig. 6.1 shows an overhead view of two cars approaching a road junction. A plane mirror helps the drivers to see other cars
On Fig. 6.2, continue the path of the ray into the block
On Fig. 6.2, clearly label the angle of incidence \(i\) and the angle of refraction \(r\)
Fig. 6.2 shows a ray of light incident on a glass block
Give the names of the two regions that are labelled 1 and 2
Use words from the box to complete the sentence
Compared with other regions in the electromagnetic spectrum, radio waves have the
Sound is not an electromagnetic wave
Give **one** other way in which sound waves are different from radio waves
Two students, X and Y, carry out an experiment to determine the speed of sound in air
X has two blocks of wood that make a loud, sharp sound when banged together
Y has a tape measure and a stopwatch
Describe how X and Y can use the equipment to measure the speed of sound in air
Fig. 7.1 shows the regions of the electromagnetic spectrum
Fig. 8.1 shows a bar magnet
On Fig. 8.1, draw lines to show the shape of the magnetic field around the bar magnet. Include at least **one** arrow to show the direction of the field
Explain how a coil of wire can be used to create a bar magnet from a suitable piece of metal
Which of these metals could be used to make a bar magnet? Tick **one** box
On Fig. 9.1, draw
* an arrow labelled X, on side CD, to show the direction of the current in this side of the coil,
* an arrow labelled P, to show the direction of the force on CD
Give two ways of increasing the forces F and P on the sides of the coil
Name the particles that flow in the metal wire of the coil
The wire of the coil is replaced by a thinner wire. This wire is the same length and is made of the same metal
State and explain how this changes the current in the coil
Fig. 9.1 shows a current-carrying coil in a magnetic field
The direction of the current in side AB of the coil is labelled
The force F on side AB is also labelled
To investigate this, the student connects the circuit shown in Fig. 10.1
The student has made three errors
Identify the **three** errors in the student's circuit
Use the information in Fig. 10.2 to describe how the brightness of the light in the room affects the resistance of the LDR
The potential difference across the LDR is 8.0 V
Calculate the current in the LDR when the light is \(60\%\) of full brightness
current =   .........  A
The student corrects the errors. His results are shown in Fig. 10.2
A student wants to investigate how the resistance of a light-dependent resistor (LDR) varies with the brightness of the light in the room
The plug for a television contains a fuse
Explain the purpose of the fuse
State the metal used for the two coils of each transformer
One transformer has an input voltage of 224 V and an output voltage of 16.0 V. The input coil contains 308 turns
Calculate the number of turns on the output coil
number of turns =   .........
The circuit of the television includes transformers
State the name of particle X
State the charge of particle X
Tick one box in Fig. 12.2 that correctly represents an isotope of lithium
A sample of lithium contains \(1.00 \text{mg}\) of a radioactive isotope of lithium
Calculate the mass of the isotope that remains after 2 half-lives
Fig. 12.1 represents the particles in an atom of the element lithium
